docs.lead_paragraph: THOMAS F. MARSICO, a star stock picker who had a knack for spotting small technology companies on the verge of becoming big hits, had become used to highflying returns -- but now he has seen his large-capitalization growth funds take a nose dive. His flagship $1.8 billion Marsico Focus fund was down 14.68 percent in the first half of this year, and the $692 million Marsico Growth and Income fund was down 12.85 percent. That compares with a loss of 6.7 percent for the the Standard & Poor's 500.

headline.main: A Longtime Star Hopes It's a Short-Term Slump

docs.abstract: Large-capitalization growth funds managed by Thomas F Marsico suffer double-digit declines in first half of year, dragged down by technology sector, from which he has largely now retreated; analysts seem confident that Marsico, whose style is to analyze macroeconomic trends and select portfolio of 20 to 30 top-name companies, can regain his golden touch; Marisco Capital Management has been acquired by Bank of America; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Motorola, the cell phone maker, provides health benefits to 230,000 workers, retirees and dependents around the country. For 40 years, in an effort to control the quality of its health plan, the company has reviewed and paid claims itself. Now, Motorola executives say, they have become acutely concerned about federal legislation to define patients' rights, and they think it could force them to change many aspects of what they do.

headline.main: Motorola, With Self-Run Health Plan, Is Wary of Rights Bill

docs.abstract: Motorola Inc has reviewed and paid health care claims of its employees for last 40 years, in effort to control quality of its health plan; company executives are concerned about federal legislation to define patients' rights, fearing that as company that rules on individual claims for health benefits, Motorola could be sued by its workers under bill passed by Senate; all major proposals for patients' bill of rights in Senate and House stipulate that health plans must allow patients to obtain independent medical review of decisions to deny care; Motorola says 'independent outside source' is asked for help in some cases, but company does not have procedure allowing patient to take initiative and demand independent medical review of decisions on claims; Sen Olympia J Snowe says only 6 percent of employers are so involved in running health plans that they could be sued by employees under Senate bill (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Like many other people, Robert Clydesdale of Newburgh, N.Y., has had his share of frustrations with managed health care. Now he is hoping to use his experiences to help other consumers, and maybe make a profit in the process. In 1987, Mr. Clydesdale became infected with Lyme disease, but he was unaware of his illness and did not receive treatment for it until eight years later. By then, his condition had deteriorated to the point where he was blind in one eye and needed a walker to get around. He also ran up substantial medical bills, which, he said, his insurer initially balked at fully paying.

headline.main: An Advocacy Business Grew From Frustration

docs.abstract: Patients America helps people win reimbursement for health care from insurers who have rejected claims; Robert Clydesdale started company a year ago after prolonged but successful effort to get his own claims reviewed (S)
